phishing_detective.subject: URGENT: Your account will be suspended!
phishing_detective.preview: Dear user, we detected suspicious activity...
phishing_detective.body:
Dear user,

We detected suspicious activity on your account. Click here immediately to verify your identity or your account will be locked within 24 hours.

[VERIFY NOW]

PayPal Security Team
redFlags: Urgency and fear tactics (24 hours, suspended)
phishing_detective.explanation: This is a classic phishing attempt. The sender domain is misspelled (paypa1 instead of paypal), uses generic greetings, and creates artificial urgency to prompt immediate action without thinking.

phishing_detective.subject: Your Netflix subscription has been renewed
phishing_detective.body:
Hi Sarah,

Your Netflix Standard subscription has been renewed for $15.49. This charge will appear on your statement as NETFLIX.COM.

Questions? Visit our Help Center.

The Netflix Team
phishing_detective.explanation: This is a legitimate email from Netflix. It has a verified domain, personalized greeting, clear transaction details, and no urgent calls to action.

phishing_detective.subject: Unusual sign-in attempt detected
phishing_detective.preview: We noticed a new login from an unrecognized device...
phishing_detective.body:
Hello,

We noticed a sign-in attempt from:
Location: Russia
Device: Unknown
Time: 2:34 AM

If this wasn't you, please secure your account immediately:
[SECURE MY ACCOUNT]

Amazon Security
phishing_detective.explanation: While this email looks more sophisticated, the .tk top-level domain is a major red flag. Legitimate Amazon emails come from @amazon.com addresses. The use of fear (Russia, unknown device) is designed to make you panic and click without thinking.

phishing_detective.subject: [GitHub] Your password was changed
phishing_detective.preview: This email confirms that your password was recently changed...
phishing_detective.body:
Hi CyberNinja,

This email confirms that your password for your GitHub account was changed on November 7, 2025 at 3:45 PM IST.

If you didn't make this change, please contact GitHub Support immediately.

Thanks,
The GitHub Team
phishing_detective.explanation: This is a legitimate security notification from GitHub. It has the correct sender domain, personalized username, specific timestamp, and provides a proper support contact without pressuring you to click suspicious links.

phishing_detective.subject: Action required: Confirm your information
phishing_detective.preview: Dear valued customer, we need you to confirm...
phishing_detective.body:
Dear valued customer,

As part of our security measures, we require you to confirm your account information. Please review and update your details within 48 hours to avoid service interruption.

Your cooperation is appreciated.

Best regards,
PayPal Customer Service
redFlags: Domain spoofing (paypal.com.secure-update.net - actual domain is secure-update.net)
phishing_detective.explanation: This is a sophisticated phishing attempt using subdomain spoofing. The email appears to come from paypal.com, but the actual domain is secure-update.net. Always check the full sender address carefully - the real domain comes AFTER the last period before the @ symbol.

feedback: Common password found in breach databases
Add special characters and uppercase letters
Common substitutions (0 for o, @ for a)
Add more length for better security
Easy to remember, hard to crack
Consider adding numbers or symbols for even more security
Perfect mix of all character types
Use a password manager to remember this

url_inspector.explanation: This is a legitimate Amazon URL with HTTPS, correct domain spelling, and a logical path structure.

url_inspector.context: Email claiming to be from PayPal
url_inspector.explanation: Multiple red flags: HTTP instead of HTTPS, suspicious .tk TLD, not the official paypal.com domain, and a generic 'verify.php' page.

url_inspector.context: Social media message from unknown sender
url_inspector.explanation: URL shorteners hide the real destination. While not always malicious, they should be treated with caution, especially from unknown sources.
Typosquatting attack using '0' (zero) instead of 'o'. This is not the real amazon.com domain.
redFlags: Account update request is common phishing tactic

url_inspector.explanation: Domain spoofing - the real domain is securityupdate.ru, not paypal.com. The subdomain tricks users.
redFlags: Security update is common phishing theme

url_inspector.explanation: Legitimate GitHub repository URL with HTTPS and proper structure. Safe to visit.
